title: Internet
text:
Where is the Internet?

A. Cloud
B. Ocean
C. Ground
D. Space

Video: Where really is the Internet?

title: Internet
text: Announcements

title: Internet
text:
Lesson Objectives



Define and identify the purpose of the following protocols:

HTTP, TLS, DNS.​

Define and identify the purpose of URLs and Browsers​
Explain how users access data across the web

how it relates to the other internet layers and protocols.

Summarize how HTTP provides access to web content

purpose of HTML, CSS, & JavaScript​

Articulate the different layers of the web

and which are accessible by search engines​






The goal of this lesson is to familiarize cadets with how the Internet actually works, specifically the application layer, and how actions they take at the application layer actually affects the lower layers as well. By the end of this lesson, students should be well versed in the different protocols that exist at the application layer, and how they work together when data is requested or sent over the Internet.

title: Internet
text:
The Internet!



What is it?
Who owns it?
Who created it?
When?
Why?

YouTube Video: Vint Cerf




What is the Internet?
Begin with the code.org video on Slide 4, which includes narration from Vint Cert (one of the ‘fathers of the internet’ along with Bob Kahn). This video is a good ice-breaker to begin discussion about what the Internet is and to dispel some misconceptions about the Internet.
Some follow-up questions could include: - the video touched on the Internet being a distributed network – what does this mean? - the video discussed the fact that the Internet is packet-switched – what does this mean? What are the benefits?

title: Internet
text:
Distributed Packet-Switched Network


What does this mean?

Distributed: No central control
Packet-Switched: Data broken into packets

What are the benefits?

Redundancy
Scalability
Flexibility




The Internet is a connection of billions of computers using the Internet Protocol’s communication rules.

title: Internet
text:
History of the Internet




What is ARPANet​?

Precursor to modern Internet​

Who created ARPANet​?

Department of Defense​

Created in the​ 1960s​
NSFNet created in mid-1980s for universities and government labs​
ARPANet connected to NSFNet in 1980s​ to create inter-network
Use of TCP/IP protocol​ ensured massive scalability






Early roots include the U.S. Dept. of Defense’s ARPANET in the 1960s. In the 1980s, the U.S. National Science Foundation funded a further network “backbone” creation known as NSFNet, connecting universities and government research labs, mostly for email and file transfers (at a time when sending letters and documents via physical mail was the norm). When ARPANET and NSFNet were merged in the late 1980s, the name Internet took over (short for “inter-networking”).

title: Internet
text:
World Wide Web


What is it?

A bunch of hypertext documents that link to each other​

What documents?

Web pages!

Is it the Internet?

No!





The web of hypertext documents (web pages) cross-referencing (linking) each other​
The World Wide Web is one use of the Internet that involves a vast collection of web pages (information) that is accessed via the Internet.
Many people may think these are synonymous, but it is important to understand the distinction in this class.

title: Internet
section: The Big 4 of the World Wide Web​
text:
The Big 4 of the World Wide Web​




Uniform Resource Locator (URL)​

pointer to a document on the network​
uniquely identifies each website

Hyper Text Transfer Protocol (HTTP)​

how browsers and servers communicate​

Browser ​

program to downloads and displays those documents​

Hyper Text Markup Language (HTML)​

language for writing those documents​







The fundamental building block of the Web is a single page of information that may include links to other pages. This is an image of a Wikipedia page, but you can pull up another website if you’d like. This example includes information (written in hypertext) along with click-able text, hyperlinks, which link the user to another webpage. This creates a “web” of interconnected information. Introduce the four (4) main components that build the web:  1. Uniform Resource Locator (URL) – Finds that file on any computer that is on the same network  2. Hyper Text Transport Protocol (HTTP) – Moves the contents of that file from the server to the client  3. Browsers – Display those documents in a readable format  4. Hyper Text Markup Language (HTML) - Represent a document with hyperlinks to any file on any computer on the Internet    Let’s discuss each of these in turn.

title: Internet
text:
Uniform Resource Locator (URL)​


URLs & DNS & HTTP (15 mins) (slide 9) In order to link pages to one another, each webpage must have a specific address, which is called a Uniform Resource Locator (URL). The components of a URL include the web’s protocol (like HTTPS), the host (the domain you wish to talk to), and the path (the page within the domain you are looking for).

title: Internet
text:
Domain Name System (DNS)​




What does it do?

Domain name -> IP address

Why is it important?

Allows us to use names instead of numbers

Who controls it?

ICANN controls root servers
Registrars control top-level domains
Companies control their subdomains

Who can own a domain?

Anyone!

Where is this massive directory stored?






https://www.akamai.com/glossary/what-are-dns-servers




(slide 10) But… in the Internet lesson, we learned that IP address are used to find things on the internet, not URL? Correct! But, how many students know the IP address for westpoint.edu?

title: Internet
section: But how does DNS really work?
text:
But how does DNS really work?




Browser: Where is www.example.com?
Resolver: Who knows about .com
Root Server: Here is your TLD server’s address
Resolver: Who knows about example.com?
TLD Server: Here is the authoritative server for example.com
Resolver: IP address for www.example.com?
Authoritative Server: 1.2.3.4
Resolver: 1.2.3.4






https://www.cloudflare.com/learning/dns/what-is-dns/




(slide 11) When you request content from a URL, the first thing that happens is a DNS (Domain Name System) lookup, which takes the domain name from the URL as an input, and replies back with the IP address of the computer that is running the applicable web server. DNS is an example of another protocol!The DNS first looks at the root of the URL (.com, .gov, etc.), then it searches for the domain, and so on.

title: Internet
text:
Hyper Text Transfer Protocol

https://medium.com/@terrybmochire/what-happens-when-you-type-a-url-in-your-browser-and-press-enter-d7357a555911
(slide 14-15) A user uses the web-browser to connect to websites that are “served” by webservers. The hyper-text transfer protocol (“http” in the URLs) in conjunction with other protocols like DNS and TCP/IP help the browser communicate with a webserver. When a “client” requests the contents from a URL, the “server” sends back the HTML which is then displayed by the web browser, a program on our computer which requests the content and renders the HTML into a viewable format for the user.
HTTP is exceptional insecure; it is highly recommended you always use HTTPS whenever you surf the web. In our programming lab in a few lessons you will see first-hand why.

title: Internet
text:
Browser




What is it?

Application on a user’s computer

Uses what protocol?

Hyper Text Transfer Protocol (HTTP)
Secure version: HTTPS

What do you enter in it?

Uniform Resource Locator (URL)

What does it do with the URL?

Gets IP address from DNS server
Requests the webpage from the server
Makes it look pretty







(slide 12) When the IP address is returned, the client (the user) sends a request to connect to the server (the IP address where content is located) for the information, following the Internet protocols and layers taught in the previous lesson.

title: Internet
text:
Web Server



Program on a computer
Listens for requests
Responds with content





Google Data Center




(slide 13) Web servers are programs located on computers (typically stored in datacenters) that run the content or services being request. A map is provided of the Google Data Centers across the world and there is a video to provide further clarify into what a “server” is.

title: Internet
text:
A Modern Web Page




How do we represent a webpage? Text, Links

HyperText!

What is the language of HyperText?

HyperText Markup Language (HTML)

Can you see HTML?

Yes!
Right-click on a page
Select “View page source”

What do you see?

title: Internet
text:
Hyper Text Markup Language

Defines the structure and content of the webpage
Developed to specify links, headers, paragraphs, images, etc.
Uses tags such as <h1>, <p>, <a>, <img>



Can you write a program in HTML?

No, but you can write a webpage!




Browsers, HTML, CSS and JavaScript (15 mins)
(slide 16-17) When we introduced the Web, we mentioned that webpages are written in hypertext and often includes hyperlinks to other webpages. Hypertext is simply plain text, but in order to add distinctions between plain text and hyperlinks, additional formatting what required. This is how Hyper Text Markup Language (HTML) was developed – a way to mark up a pages to specify links, headers, paragraphs, images, etc.
(slide 18) Keep in mind, HTML is not a programming language like Python is; it is simply a markup language. That means, HTML cannot perform tasks and analyze logical conditions. It is just use to define the structure and content of a website.
HTML (HyperText Markup Language) generally defines the content and some of the layout and format of the webpage.

title: Internet
Internet
Internet
Internet
text:
In-Class Exercise

Create a webpage!
Add style and interactivity
ZyBooks - 22.2 ICE: World Wide Web
Reference: W3 Schools


(Slide 21) ICE – Make a Webpage
Have students create a folder on their computer and download the files from the Canvas ICE: World Wide Web activity. This activity give the students starter code to copy into html, CSS or JS files to create their own webpage and provides links to W3 Schools to explore further. https://www.w3schools.com/html/
The intent of this ICE is for the student to be creative and change their webpage as they want. There are not prescribes tasks, except a suggestion to change paragraph text. If a student does not know where to begin or what to change, you can provide the following suggestions:
HTML: Can you change the header to a sub header? (change h1 tags to h2 or h3)?
Can you add a new paragraph sentence that says “Go Army”?
Can you change the hyperlink in “CY105” to be the West Point home page?
CSS: Can you move the header to be center aligned?
Can you change the background color of the webpage?
JS: When you click on the image of a pony, can you hide the text “Beat Navy!”?

title: Internet
text:
Cloud Computing




What is it?

Someone else’s computer!

Why is it useful?

Little to no software installation
Applications managed by the provider
Lower cost
Eliminates the need for physical media
Seamless transition between many devices







Cloud Computing (10 mins) Today, we often utilize the processing resources, data, and storage available on the Internet available via different applications. This is called cloud computing and is in contract to local processing and storage that would utilize your specific computers hardware resources. Cloud applications process and deliver data located on remote servers that are accessible via the Internet. Cloud applications have advantages over local drive applications, including:
Little to no software installation: Many applications in the cloud run on remote servers and process or stream data in real-time, thus alleviating users from having to download large software programs that require significant amounts of disk space.

Up-to-date software: Applications running on the cloud are the most recent releases.

Lower cost: Some software applications are very expensive. For example, the Adobe Creative Suite 6 Master Collection, a drawing, photo, and video editing suite, once cost $2,599. Adobe Creative Cloud has moved to a subscription model that offers the same suite of applications for $50 a month, which is cheaper if only needed for a short time.

Eliminates the need for physical media: To listen to music or watch videos on the computer, users could only play physical disks (CDs, DVDs) or media files on the local drive. Current applications like Netflix and Spotify allow users to stream videos and music in the respective online libraries.

Access from many locations and devices: Cloud applications can be accessed by various user devices and from various locations.
ZyBook also discusses the concept of cloud storage, which is the storage of files on remotely-located servers, with those files being managed by apps via the web. Cloud storage has several advantages over storing files solely on a local computer drive:

Local storage is limited. Moving lesser-used files to cloud storage, such as large video files, can make room in local storage for more regularly-used files.
Files on cloud storage can serve as a backup. A backup is a copy of a file kept in case the local version is accidentally damaged or lost.
Files on cloud storage can be accessed by various user devices and from various locations.

title: Internet
text:
Business Models

Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS)

Pay for access to raw computing resources
Amazon Web Services (AWS)

Platform as a Service (PaaS)

Pay for access to platforms or toolkits
Google App Engine

Software as a Service (SaaS)

Pay for applications
Microsoft Office 365



Cloud Computing has also led to the introduction of new business models and impacted the way people conduct business. ZyBook mentions the following:

Software as a service (Saas) is a type of business model where users pay for a vendor’s apps, which process and store data on the cloud.
Infrastructure as a service (IaaS) is a type of business model where users pay to access computing resources such as servers, storage, and networking. Example: Amazon Web Services (AWS)
Platform as a service (PaaS) is a type of business model where users pay to access vendor’s platforms or toolkits to develop and deploy new applications. Example: Google App Engine.
Telecommuting, where an employee works outside of the traditional office space, has also increased due to the ability for cloud computing.

title: Internet
text:
Discussion: Search Engines

What is a search engine? Give some examples.
How does it work? How often does a search engine contact other websites?
What can it not find?
Can you work without it? Why or why not?

YouTube: How Search Works

Search Engines & Layers of the Web (5 mins)
By now, students should understand the process and protocols in place to request web content and receive it back. But what if the user does not know the URL for their desired content? Where do you go if you don’t know the exact page you want to request? Website such as www.google.com or yahoo, are what is called search engines. A search engine is a website that does web searches – takes user-typed words as an input and finds the web pages that best match.
(Slide 43) A Code.org video explains search engines and search algorithms. (play ~ 0:44 – 3:50)
Key takeaways: - Search engines do not go out to the WWW every time there is a new search to find the best answers - Spiders continuously creates and updates a search index which is then referenced to find the best answers - Algorithms for what is “the best” result(s) can vary and are often evolving to improve results and detect spammers.

title: Internet
text:
Deep and Dark Web



Surface Web

Publicly accessible World Wide Web
Search engine spider can see this!

Deep Web

Private, unlinked, or hidden
Hidden behind login pages
Unlinked, excluded by robots.txt
Search engines cannot see this!

Dark Web

Anonymizing protocols

Unusual routing techniques
Lots of Encryption

I2P, Freenet, ZeroNet, GNUnet
Commonly accessed using The Onion Router (TOR) browser 

Do not try this yourself!





(slides 23 - 24) The content that the engine spider indexes makes up the surface web. This is only 4% of the total web content out there! Below the “surface”, is the deep web, content that is hidden behind login pages or proprietary information not accessible to the general public. Then there is the dark web, requiring specific networks, browsers, and software to enable anonymous routing protocols and often used for illegal activity, such as black-market trading and counterfeiting.

title: Internet
text:
Cloud Computing and Data

If you create content but it is stored on the cloud (another company’s web server), who owns the data?
What if the user and the data locations expands multiple countries? What rules are then in place to protect the contents?
What implications does cloud services have on data privacy?


Interesting questions to pose to the class. If there is time in class, these questions could lead to great discussions, but if not, share these as teasers for the upcoming Data and Ethics lesson.

If you create content but it is stored on the cloud (another company’s web server), who owns the data?
What if the user and the data locations expands multiple countries? What rules are then in place to protect the contents?
What implications does cloud services have on data privacy?

title: Internet
text:
Check on Learning

What is the Internet?
Who owns the Internet?
What is the World Wide Web?
How does the WWW work?
Does DNS translate URLs to domain names?
What is the purpose of HTTP?
What is a browser?
Is a browser a server or a client?


Define the internet. Who owns it? What is the world wide web? How is it different from the internet? Describe how the Domain Name System (DNS) relates to IP Addresses and Uniform Resource Locators (URLs). How does the WWW work? Define and describe the following terms: HTTP/HTTPS HTML URL Client vs Server CSS JavaScript Define a browser. Provide some examples of them.

title: Internet
text:
Final Notes

Can build a website!

title: Computing Fundamentals
text: This course introduces the fundamentals of computing and cyberspace and blends theoretical knowledge with the practical application of computer hardware, software (programming), and cyberspace. Emphasis is placed on developing critical thinking skills and understanding the legal, ethical, and professional considerations as well as the challenges, opportunities, and attributes of the cyber domain.

title: Computing Fundamentals
text:
Course Objectives

Examine legal, ethical, professional, and security issues associated with the cyber domain.
Function as an ethical, secure, and competent user in West Point’s immersive technology and cyber environment.
Apply sequential logic, control flow statements, and code libraries using a modern programming language, algorithmic thinking, and a problem-solving process.
Describe how data flows from data sources across air, land, sea, and cyberspace to form a network of information that is constantly being tracked and exploited by allies, adversaries, and third parties.
Describe and explore the opportunities and challenges presented by artificial intelligence in the modern world.

title: Computing Fundamentals
text:
Additional Instruction

Complete required readings and in-class exercises.
Book a meeting
Come prepared with specific questions and bring your computer!

Plan ahead and do not wait until the assignment due date! Note that once you setup a meeting for additional instruction, it becomes your assigned place of duty. If you cannot make it, please notify me as early as possible.
